values:
It's typhoon again in Taiwan, I'm sort of getting a bit sick of typhoons these days, it was fun to start with, but now I just think it makes the city lifeless with all the shops closed. On the other hand it does make the temperature a lot more bearable.

I'm getting a bit upset that I'll be leaving this Sunday, I mean the two months have passed so quickly, I've made so many friends here and had so much fun. Man, hate to think about going back to Edinburgh, I mean it's a nice city, but I know that next year will be really really hard, and I doubt I'll get much time to go out. Oh, and there won't the the convenience of Taipei with hundreds of cheap and delicious restaurants, 24 hour convenience stores and the ultra cool metro system.

Oh, by the way, the previous two posts about Naomi and I was just for a bit of fun, but I think some of you believed it. You see Naomi had used my Mac to read my blog, and since I didn't sign out previously, she thought it'd be fun to write something on it. I was tempted to delete it, but I was convinced that leaving it on would be fun.

So basically I'm still the same ol' single Joe you lads and lasses had come to know and love.

So today I have finally got to hang out with the girl that I fancy. Her name is Naomi. I do believe that she is the most wonderful person I have ever met. Her beauty makes me feel so overwhelmed...I don't know how I got so lucky as to be able to occupy even a moment of her time. I feel like this whole time that I have been in Taiwan has been so wonderful and amazing..but nothing compared to the time when I am with her. I'm doing well..and I'm in love.

It's around 2am in the morning, but I just wanted to get this entry in before I go off to bed. At around midnight I was getting a bit hungry, so i decided to go to Family Mart to get some snacks. As I stepped out of the house I heard a cat's meow, I turned to look down and I saw a little black cat crouched beneath a motorcycle. I didn't pay much attention to it and continued my journey, but for some reason the cat reminds me of Kumiko. After I got some cold noodle I headed back towards the flat, and when I got to the door the cat was still there, and made some desperate sounding "meow meow" as if its hungry, I tried to ignore it since I thought its going to be OK, and I shouldn't risk upsetting nature's animal ecosystem (is that the way to say it?), but the cat kept going "meow meow meow" I could hear it even after I got in the door. After I had my noodle I just couldn't bear thinking about the poor hungry cat outside, that I decided to put some milk in the plastic bow, and took it down to the cat, I placed the bowl down, and the cat gave it a weary look, it was really shy and wouldn't come forward. Shy and small? This is Kumiko! I took a few steps back and eventually the cat came forward, it gave the milk a sniff but then settled back without even taking a sip! By now Neil came out; since he was also hungry too, so we both tried to convince it to drink the milk, but all we managed to do was scared it under a car. I place the bow under the car and thought it might be better if we leave it there for a while, so Neil and I went to 7-Eleven (I didn't want to go back to Family Mart again). When we came back we found that the cat was still there, and the milk was not touched, so I said: "Come on Kumiko, you have to drink it" "Are we calling this cat Kumiko?" asked Neil "Yup" "OK Kumiko come on" said Neil I decided that I'd offer Kumiko some Kyushu Seaweed Crisps that I'd just bought; since Kyushu is where she's from, but she didn't eat it. I got annoyed and tried to talk some sense into her using both Chinese and English, but she was a stubborn cat. So I took the milk back into the house and left it to its "meow meow meow" life outside.

First of all, I made a silly mistake in telling many of you in the e-mail saying that I'm here to study English. And some of you were confused by that. I'm here to improve my Chinese! I think I probably shouldn't write while I'm tired.

Now that's clear up, let me update you all on what's been happening here, there's so much to write about that I'm not even sure where to begin. Well last Tuesday Rory, Neil, James and I went to Warner Village Cinema, to my disappointment the closest film to a Chinese film is Unleashed starring Jet Li, so we upped for that, since we had an hour to wait we decided to go to the games arcade upstairs and Neil and James had an air hockey game which Neil won, Rory and I then had a game on the small table, and we won a game each, when Neil beat James on the big table, Rory and I decided to to move on to the big table for the deciding match which I won. After that I also beat Neil and James, so I was the champion!

I have to say that Unleashed was just a terrible film, I was shocked when I realised that the film was set in Glasgow, but. Without ANY Glaswegian people, there's not a single bit of Scottish accent in this film, everyone had either a English or American accent, and when Jet Li went to Spar for some grocery, they put it in a paper bag! Is this an American version of Glasgow? It gets worse, instead of neds raiding the shop, they were basically the kind of gangs you'll see in American films. Somebody please stop these Americans from ruining other cultures.

There seem to be a lot of interest in my pink shirt, I wore it this morning to the orientation, and I can report I had no stares in my direction and neither did any boys tried to approach me.

We've all heard of the advice "be yourself" when you try to impress the opposite sex. Well I was asking my big sister in Taipei - who I adopted in Edinburgh last year - about how I should introduce myself in Chinese to girls in night clubs here. And she told me that I should speak English to them! Of course I was pretty confused by that; she explains that Taiwanese girls love ABCs and BBCs (American Born Chinese and British Born Chinese), and if I were to speak Chinese, I should put on an foreigner's accent. Of course I thought this is ridiculous, imagine impressing a girl by pretending to have less ability than you really have!

Last night I took a walk around the university area where all the food places are, only to find that all the vegetarian shops were closed (it was already around 9pm), and the normal places in Taiwan tend to be really meaty.

Tapei is a very mixed up city, at night it doesn't look unlike Tokyo with all the lit up sign boards and modern looking shops and restaurants, but during the day you'll see lots of buildings that's old and dirty on the outside from the first floor onwards. What's strange is that in between these dirty old buildings you'll see ultra new modern glass panel towers, although doesn't matter whether the building is new or old, the interiors tend to be quite nice all the time.

Because I'm near the university area, there're lots of foreigners about the place, last night I saw a group buskin (someone tell me how you spell this word) in the park, they were shit, but that didn't seemed to stop them from having a big crowd; since it's still amusing to see exotic westerners on their guitars.

Times have changed and Taiwan has changed too. There're too many things here that I'm not familiar with; such as the recycling rules, Taipei is way ahead of anywhere in Britain when it comes to recycling, there're three rubbish collections a day, and if you don't sort out your rubbish to different categories they wouldn't take it. Also when you buy things from a shop, they'll ask you if you need a bag, if so you'll have to pay for it.

Taiwan has surprising large amount of luxury cars, there're huge number of Mercedes and BMWs, my guess is that in Taiwan people like to be seen to have a high status, coincidentally you'll often see a hot chick in one of those cars, but the guys tend to look like a pig. Maybe I'm just jealous?

Speaking of which, Taipei has so many pretty girls, I found myself turning my head here and there like a little boy in Disney Land. This is how the world should be, I'm always jealous of boys living in places where nice girls are the norm. I was speaking to a Dutch gentlemen (who was a business class passenger working for a big Dutch bank "AB Amro") when our plane stopped off at Bangkok, he said that he thinks there're a lot of men who go to Thailand for the girls there, and I said I'm not surprised judging by the scenery in the airport. So Ruairidh, we know why you're there!

Hey everyone

Just to let you all know everything's going very well here, and my luck has been pretty good ever since I arrived, the really amazing thing is I saw someone I know in the airport while I was waiting for the airport bus! Although he was driving a van and didn't see me, so I ran after him around the airport pushing the trolly with lots of luggage for what seemed like forever, I was sweating and roasting, and about to collapse, sadly I didn't make it.

Everything is going great here, I registered in the uni this morning, and found it really strange to see so many foreign students here from many countries all speaking in Chinese to each other. I got a home stay from a woman who's son and daughter both went to a university in Britain!

Anyway, that's all for now, more coming later.

Joe

After god knows how many phone calls and sleepless nights I'm finally off! I'm on the plane as I'm typing this. For those of you don't know what's going on, I'm heading off to Taipei for two months to learn Chinese at the National Taiwan Normal University (bit of a mouthful isn't it).

"Wait Joe, don't you already know Chinese?" I hear you ask, well you see even though I can speak fluent Chinese; but because I've never been to school in Taiwan, the only Chinese characters I can write are the ones I've learned from Japanese! But hopefully I'll be able to pick up writing Chinese real quick.

Of cause life isn't just about learning, it's about having fun in different times zones and meet different people. I plan to eat smelly tofu and drink pearl milk tea every day, oh and ride motorbike like crazy,
